Father and son with shared name, love of laughter die days apart of coronavirus ...  their 46th wedding anniversary this year in Cancun. Right after high school, Taylor Jr. was offered and accepted into a job program through General Motors. He went to the GM Institute in Flint to study for six weeks at a time, followed by six weeks of work at Detroit Diesel Allison. He continued that rotation until he became a full-time employee. He worked for General Motors/Rolls-Royce for 41 years and retired as a journeyman tool and die maker in July 2013. Roscoe Taylor III graduated from Arlington High School in 1995. While at Arlington, he became the manager of the varsity football team and had such a positive impact on the team that during their awards ceremony, they presented him with a letterman's jacket. McLaren is laying off 25% of its workforce as coronavirus halts races, manufacturing and sales ...  worldwide. Some support and back office roles will also be affected. The news comes after Formula 1 revealed plans this month to introduce a new annual cost cap of $145 million for 2021, down from $175 million. McLaren is the latest in a line of manufacturers to announce layoffs as a result of the coronavirus crisis. Last week, the U.K.'s Rolls Royce announced it was laying off 9,000 of its 52,000 workers to adapt to the much-smaller aviation market. Disclosure: CNBC has a partnership with McLaren . TUI surges in London as airline stocks rally on summer tourist season hopes ...  with a prolonged period of minimal revenue with monthly cash burn of around 600 million. TUI's chief executive told the Rheinische Post that it planned to resume flights at the end of June. Other travel stocks rallied in London as well, with Iberia owner International Consolidated Airlines Group IAG, +19.49% jumping 20% and easyJet EZJ, +15.89% rallying 17%. Airline engine maker Rolls-Royce RR, +11.26% surged 11%. The broader FTSE 100 UKX, +1.06% rose 1.2% to 6062.83, with markets across the world advancing on hopes for reopenings and news of a new vaccine trial starting. Inside the RAF's most mocked fighter aircraft ... for the RAF The rear machine gun position dramatically reduced the aircraft's top speed By Darren Boyle for MailOnline Published: 07:02 EDT, 26 May 2020 | Updated: 07:02 EDT, 26 May 2020 e-mail View comments A World War II aircraft which was sent to a museum in 1944 was far deadlier than its reputation suggests, according to a historian. The Boulton Paul Defiant had a Rolls Royce Merlin engine - just like the acclaimed Spitfire and Hurricane - but it also had a second seat with a machine gun turret for blasting enemy bombers out of the sky. When it was first introduced into service, Luftwaffe pilots initially mistook the aircraft for a Hurricane and would attempt to roll in behind the aircraft to shoot it down only to be faced by its deadly Browning .303 ...

Travel shares soar on FTSE 100 amid hopes holiday curbs will ease ... 39;s 9bn (8bn) bailout of the Lufthansa airline . Airline and hotel companies were the best UK performers during morning trading, as British Airways owner International Airlines Group (IAG) soared 15% and Intercontinental Hotels Group jumped more than 14%. Whitbread, the pubs group and owner of the Premier Inn chain, also rose 14%. Budget carrier EasyJet rose 11.5%, along with jet engine maker Rolls-Royce which climbed 9%, while cruise operator Carnival was 11% higher. Investors were boosted by Boris Johnson's decision to set out a timeline for the reopening of outdoor markets and car showrooms in England from 1 June. He stole millions and spent like crazy. Now Towson Ponzi schemer Kevin Merrill’s tainted bounty hits the auction block ...  his loot from federal agents. Meanwhile, a court-appointed team set out to sell everything and repay his victims: investment groups, retirees, small-business owners, doctors and professional athletes, most of them wealthy too. Efforts to locate and sell Merrill's possessions have continued for nearly two years. He owned a fleet of about 20 exotic sports cars — Rolls Royce, Bugatti, Lamborghini. His collection of rare comic books was valued at $200,000; his fine wine collection, $150,000. Prosecutors estimated his Louis Vuitton wardrobe at nearly $1 million.
